sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The country farmer's vain-glory in a new song of harvest home: together with an answer to their undecent behaviour. Sung to a new tune much in request. Licensed according to order.
1 sheet ([1] p.) : ill. (woodcuts)
Printed for P. Brooksby, J. Dencon [sic], J. Balre and J. Back, [London] : [1695]
Verse - "Our oats they are how'd, and our barley's reap'd". Place of publication from Wing, which estimates 1688-1695 as publication date. Sheet includes two songs; second part has title: An answer to Harvest home: or, A true character of such country-men who glory in cheating the vicar, & prefer bag-pudding & dumpling before religion & learning. To the tune of Harvest home. Printed in two colums with woodcuts at head of each part. Reproduction of the original in the Glasgow University Library.
=======
The country farmer's vain-glory in a new song of harvest home: together with an answer to their undecent behaviour. Sung to a new tune much in request. Licensed according to order.
1 sheet ([1] p.) : ill. (woodcuts)
Printed for P. Brooksby, J. Dencon [sic], J. Balre and J. Back, [London] : [1695]
Verse - "Our oats they are how'd, and our barley's reap'd". Place of publication from Wing, which estimates 1688-1695 as publication date. Sheet includes two songs; second part has title: An answer to Harvest home: or, A true character of such country-men who glory in cheating the vicar, & prefer bag-pudding & dumpling before religion & learning. To the tune of Harvest home. Printed in two colums with woodcuts at head of each part. Reproduction of the original in the Glasgow University Library.
J. Back
J. Balre
J. Dencon [sic]
P. Brooksby
